review_title: Diversity for You, Diversity For Me!
pros:
Monroe has been my family for five years, from my Bachelor's to my Master's degree and even my husband. Being an international student away from home,  family and friends, one never knows what to expect when travelling to a foreign country for higher education. In my case, I was faced with the vast exposure of numerous international students like myself, creating a diverse higher educational network. You learn from your peers, as do they from you. On Campus opportunities are available, it is up to you to make your self readily available to receive it. 
I was mentored by faculty and student's like myself in the Academic Center in New Rochelle, then later became a mentor to give back the assistance and knowledge I received from those before me. The comfort and possibility of transitioning into such a position while pursuing your degree is up to you, but the opportunity is available. Upon completion of my undergraduate degree, I received a position at the Career Services Dept. on the Bronx Campus, working with some of the most hard working, patient, driven, skillful, knowledgeable, understanding and loving teammates, headed by the most awesome leader I know. Currently pursuing my Master's Degree at Monroe College, I met and married the man of my dreams and have to say, thank you Monroe College. You have not only given me higher education, but open the door to a new and memorable life. 
I must say that everyone's experience is not the same, therefore, I have no negative remarks. My advise, is come try it out for yourself and see if it fits. I sure know that it did for me.  
YAY!!!! Go Mustangs!!!
cons: None at the moment.

job_title: Career Advisor in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Great place to work, very diverse student, staff and faculty population. Room for growth and professional development.
cons: Work load can be a lot.

pros: Supportive staff and faculty, flexible work environment, very open to feedback.
cons: Having to teach six courses a semester is quite a lot, but doable.

pros: The students are really what motivate you to do what is best for them. They have so much potential. Vacation encouraged. Won't get fired as long as you do "what you have to do."
cons: No real growth, measly 3-4% merit raise annually, the people, managers, directors are all so fake, they only care about money not the students, bring in as many students as possible, NO WORK LIFE BALANCE! Late nights early mornings mandatory Saturday and after events you still stay and WORK LIKE SLAVE! Eye balling you if you leave just after 5, intimidation and scare tactics is the management style, idiots, this is not a place of higher ed, they forget its a college, function like a business..and the beat goes on and on and on!

job_title: Social Sciences Professor in Bronx, NY
pros:
Monroe has a very student and professor focus which creates a culture of community learning amongst students, staff and faculty. 

Each classroom has large televisions that are connected to the computers, which allows for easy access to showing videos, presentations, and other forms of digital tools.

Professors are offered a good deal of autonomy and are supported by the administration with formal trainings, informal conversations, and a friendly atmosphere.
cons: There is little to complain about Monroe College.  However, if we could make things better, we could offer better wifi, a public café/bookstore for the community, a recreation room and a gym for students.  Again, not a complaint, just things that could enhance the college.

pros: I have had some great opportunities in terms of growth and learning new areas in within higher education/Monroe College. The Managers I have worked with have provided me with a platform to utilize my skill set and not be "Pigeon Holed" into the specific department  I was hired for. The flexibility and freedom to move into different areas and take on different responsibilities has made this a positive professional experience for me. I have also enjoyed the culture, fun school wide events and traditions - Family oriented combined with a caring work culture. I loved the student centered focus !
cons:
Miscommunication can happen within the same department because there are two campuses, this can be a negative for the students because of different protocols for each campus.  
- More professional development opportunities for all levels ( limited budget )

pros: I became an Admissions Advisor because I wanted to empower the students and parents I work with to envision a different (and better) future from the one they originally thought was their only option. I came to Monroe because they have the same passion and purpose.  Everything they do centers on the individual student's success and how Monroe can improve on what they are already doing to ensure that goal is met.
cons: The only con could be that Monroe wants to provide so many opportunities to as many deserving students as possible, but are limited by their resources and personnel in order to make this happen.

pros: After working for 30 years in the financial industry coming to Monroe College was like a breath of fresh air.  The management is extremely supportive and has created an environment that feels like family.  Many of my colleagues have been here for decades.  A  testament to management and to the student first rewarding nature of the job.  Monroe College is an important part of the educational community here in the Bronx . The School does an amazing job offering opportunities to High School students and Adult learners.
cons: Hard to take a break.  Always work to be done.  Extremely busy

review_title: Worked at Monroe for 17 years.  Taught at Bronx campus.
pros: College is committed to student success and supports faculty and staff who further that goal.  Monroe provides supplemental services to assist students achieve their objectives.  There is a very strong "family" atmosphere.  99 % of people at the college are willing to go extra steps to help students.  Students recognize they are not just numbers, they are seen as people.
cons: Space is tight, but well kept.  Neighborhood does not capture image of college campus, but overall it is something you can get used to.  .

review_title: A Place Where You Can Make a Difference and Feel Valued
pros:
I started working at Monroe College three years ago and would highly recommend it as a great place to work. 

I’m still impressed every day by the incredible commitment of faculty and staff to help students succeed. The senior administrators are very focused on students’ success. They talk a lot about making sure that we are providing exceptional support and customer service to help students in the classroom and beyond. The talk is backed up by action – making sure they hire people with the “can do, go the extra mile” mindset and the experience to know how to make a difference. 

We work hard. You have to be willing to roll up your sleeves.  They keep the teams toward the lean side, so this is not the place for those who want to coast or be anonymous in the crowd. 

I have a long commute to work every day, but I do it gladly because there’s something to be said for knowing the work you do matters. At the risk of sounding a bit dramatic, the college has a real impact on the lives of its students – and I’m proud to be a part of that.

Holiday bonuses on top of increases a month ago were a great surprise.
cons: The College has two campuses in NY and there is a subtle us vs them vibe at times. You hear it in comments like, “We don’t go to that. It’s a New Rochelle  event.”

review_title: The environment is student-centered and employee friendly.
pros: Faculty and staff are committed to student success and will go out of their way to provide assistance.  Great team spirit among staff.  Management is approachable and open to new ideas.
cons: The college is progressive and sincerely tries to provide a high quality education for students and a good environment for staff.  I have not experienced any cons yet.

pros: Colleagues who work hard in spite of conditions
cons:
Full time professors work 6 exhausting classes fall and spring with approximately 30 students per class
Forced to work summer semester - 6 classes as well - three semesters! (trimesters)
No salary increase, no appreciation, poor medical plan
Management expects us to plan emergencies, illness, weddings, bereavements and graduations during break
Supervisors resent when faculty takes a day off - we are intimidated to not use entitled days off

review_title: Contract Dispute with No Negotiation - Take it or Leave It
job_title: Assistant Track and Field Coach in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Great student-athletes who are looking to succeed.
cons: No communication when they renew your contract.  They  cut my contract in half five days before i was to start and they fired two coaches so to cut my contract in half did not make sense as the college is an hour away from my home.  They basically said take it or leave it so I left.  Put me in a financial strain but it factored out to lime $2/hour working for them.

pros: None! Don't be fooled or believe the fancy talk given at interviews. The promises about growth and being paid well are all lies.
cons:
-Extreamly Poor Management!!!!!!! Can't say this enough. 
-No Work life balance
-Poor compensation 
-Hires minorities and underpays them 
-Paid good if your well liked, which is few people and is depending on our "background"
-Expected to work like a dog to reach unrealistic quotas all while being threatened about losing your job if you don't meet the number in the end 
-This place is a gossip mill and everyone talks about everyone and management is even involved. Sad thing is they believe everything they hear and they judge you on it and base your movement and pay off the rumors they have been told about you
-Hard work DOES NOT PAY OFF HERE! Don't be fooled by the nice personalities you will meet on an interview. RUN!!!
-This is an ultimate last resort, have to be desperate for a job place to work

job_title: Senior Admissions Counselor in Bronx, NY
pros: 1/2 day on Friday and Saturday. Former head of the college was great to staff and actually was compassionate. He will be missed by many long term employees still there.
cons:
Management Is absolutely horrific! Minorities are hired to work like slaves. Department is so understaffed with quality individuals that people end up doing multiple jobs, working long hours and at times getting burnt out. They give no significant raises that actually incentivize people to want to stay here and work hard. The turn over rate is insane. People last two to five years, possibly less for the ones who wise up quickly, and then they are gone. They continue to hire young people fresh out of college who cannot do the job but they can get away with paying peanuts.

They provide zero quality training. In their eyes these annual meetings they have where higher ups come to basically speak to staff and tell them what needs to be promoted, is their idea of "training". You either learn the admissions counselor role on your own as you go, or from experienced staff, or you don't point blank. 

They make you work a late night and alternate Saturdays which they NEVER tell you about when you interview with them. 

Several times management, including higher ups, have said several inappropriate and racist comments towards minority staff and basically brushed it off as no big deal since in their eyes you are beneath them and they are doing you a favor by employing you so either stay shut or leave.  Which sadly many people who are left working there have either been there for over 10-20yrs and are stuck or they have a family and they can't afford to not be working. Sad but true. 

Work life balance sucks and they could careless. As long as you slave for them they are ok. Management actually calls people who take a sick day and badgers them asking why they are not at work even though they are entitled to five sick days and are not required to supply a doctors note if  they are sick...ILLEGAL!! 

They love to rub in your face how "Everyone likes to get paid so we need to enroll more students". If that doesn't make you feel pressure or like your job is on the line I don't know what does.

Staff is iffy. Some work very hard and some do bare minimum while others are just purely lazy and seem to get away with it, even promoted which is a joke. Depending on who you mix well with you will either be ok or you will have it rough. Meaning people who work here are very sneaky and can't be trusted. They smile in your face but talk about you behind your back or even worse go to management and create lies which then jeopardizes your job. Lots of favoritism here, so much it's sickening.

pros: I had a great experience as a student and now as an employee. Everyone I come in contact with at the college loves what they do and helps students to their best. Personally, I love working at Monroe.
cons: There are no cons in my opinion.

pros: Salaries are slightly above basic depending on employment level,  a little bit of flexibility with work schedules
cons: Promotions in name only or among a select few individuals, too many micro-managers, obvious power struggles amongst upper management

pros: They have great athletic and culinary programs.  They pay a little more than other comparable schools .  Great 401k benefits and health savings accounts.  Fridays are half day.  They offer employees the option to take their courses free of charge. A lot of country club events (required to attend) but also nice .   They provide students who otherwise couldn't access higher education (because of grades, financial constraints,  undocumented or illegal immigrants , and those with felony or criminal history ) the opportunity to attend college.
cons: They overwork you,  expect you to work weekends, evenings, and early mornings .  Your also required to attend the mojority of sporting events (weekends and nights) along with working random weekends (with very little notice) as well as 1 late night a week until 730pm.  You must be in by 830 am and they take attendance and record the exact minute you arrive (even if you worked late or weekends when not required). Upper management is threatening , intimidating, and overall unprofessional.  Everything is last minute, and backwards and as a result staff is forced to undo or re-do what has to be done or a project suffers because of time constraints.  No opportunity for professional development.  Those who have prior experience in higher ed or student affairs find the ability to implement change so difficult.  The service, educational standards, housing facilities is substandard,  and not cost effective.

pros: Early end on Fridays and summer hours. Inclusion with banquets and some other student events.
cons: The management is too involved with the personal lives of employees and their is definitely preferential treatment of certain employees. A lot of empty promises and constant change of policies. I would not recommend them as an employer to anyone.

pros:
Passionate, talented, caring, fun people (staff & faculty)
Employees are valued and respected
Work-life balance is respected
Growth opportunities are abundant
Curiosity and continual learning highly encouraged
Core values encourage a high level of collaboration, trust, and respect
Family oriented work culture
cons: Growth is encouraged, promotions are hard to get and it's easy for communication to break down between departments/campuses.

pros: Great environment to work in. Very family oriented and easy to speak with higher ups. They give young professionals an opportunity to grow and develop.
cons: The New Rochelle and Bronx campus are not as cohesive. They feel like two different institutions

pros: You get out early on fridays. Free coffee and teas. The holiday party is awesome. If you want a forever job, you can make it here.
cons: Poor employee morale. Nepotism. Leadership only listens to those who look like them.
